即使按照中美洲境况不佳的民主国家的标准，危地马拉 6 月 25 日的选举也是不祥之兆。由于无法令人信服的原因，选举法庭禁止三名受欢迎的候选人参选。著名调查记者何塞·鲁本·萨莫拉 (José Rubén Zamora) 被法院监禁。因此，当一名局外人不顾民意调查，紧随其后，紧随该国统治精英支持的候选人而屈居第二时，对许多危地马拉人来说是一个惊喜。年轻的进步党塞米拉（种子）的贝尔纳多·阿雷瓦洛 (Bernardo Arévalo) 在 8 月份的决选中以 12% 的选票赢得一席之地。他确实有机会成为该国的下一任领导人。

64岁的阿雷瓦洛先生的投票表明了这个腐败盛行、民主标准不断下降的国家渴望变革的迹象。 （留空或破坏选票的选民比投票给任何一位候选人的选民都多，这是他们不满的表现。）阿雷瓦洛仅落后前第一夫人桑德拉·托雷斯四个百分点。他还击败了政治、军事和商业精英青睐的其他候选人，危地马拉人谴责这些候选人是“腐败者的契约”。塞米拉党将国会议员人数从 7 人增加到 23 人，成为第三大党。

这一令人惊讶的结果为绝望的地区带来了一线希望。危地马拉的许多邻国都处于独裁状态或正在走向独裁。丹尼尔·奥尔特加镇压了尼加拉瓜的反对派。在萨尔瓦多，纳伊布·布克莱已经控制了国家的所有三个部门，并说服萨尔瓦多人为此赞扬他。 6 月 26 日，他的政党表示他将竞选连任，尽管宪法似乎禁止这样做。洪都拉斯许多主要政客被认为腐败，其中一些人与毒贩和其他犯罪分子勾结。去年担任该国总统的胡安·奥兰多·埃尔南德斯被引渡到美国，面临贩毒指控。 （他不认罪。）

危地马拉已经走下坡路，特别是自 2019 年以来，时任总统吉米·莫拉莱斯关闭了CICIG这一不受支持的反腐败机构。在现任总统亚历杭德罗·贾马泰 (Alejandro Giammattei) 的领导下，法院被政治化，匿名威胁迫使数十名具有独立思想的法官和记者离开该国。

相比之下，阿雷瓦洛先生拥有强大的民主资历。作为该国第一位民选总统的儿子，他于 1945 年至 1951 年间任职，他承诺加大开放力度，打击腐败，并在教育和卫生方面投入更多资金以减少贫困。世界银行估计，一半以上的危地马拉人生活在国家贫困线以下。托雷斯女士的承诺大致相同，但对大多数危地马拉人来说，这似乎并没有改变。她的反对率远远高于阿雷瓦洛先生。

危地马拉普遍的不满情绪表明，像阿雷瓦洛这样的反建制候选人应该是第二轮获胜的热门人选。但他的敌人会让事情变得困难。对塞米拉的支持始于年轻人，塞米拉的 2019 年候选人、前总检察长被禁止参选。他们反过来说服他们的父母和祖父母投票支持该党。

但危地马拉城圣卡洛斯大学的里卡多·萨恩斯表示，统治精英是“可怕的敌人”，他们会做出“甚至是不可想象的事情”来确保阿雷瓦洛先生失败。社交媒体和其他地方已经开始有声音说阿雷瓦洛先生是一名共产主义者，他将把企业国有化。 （没有证据表明这一点。）更肮脏的伎俩可能会随之而来。

危地马拉此前曾一度处于变革的边缘，但最终却令人失望。 2015 年，在CICIG提供了针对奥托·佩雷斯·莫利纳 (Otto Pérez Molina) 的腐败证据后，成千上万的危地马拉人庆祝了他辞去总统职务。然后是莫拉莱斯先生。这次没有联合国支持的机构提供帮助。但塞米拉充满希望。塞米拉议员塞缪尔·佩雷斯表示，精英们“认为控制国家、法院和检察官就足够了”。 “但他们忘记了人民的意愿也很重要。” ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 19:52:43 GMT /内容/f6nk27op206cd5n46t8tln70r11oj2p8 https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2023/06/28/guatemalas-election-products-a-pleasant-surprise Can Ukraine capitalise on chaos in Russia?

6 月 24 日，乌克兰人高兴地看着俄罗斯陷入内战。他们原本希望叶夫根尼·普里戈任进军莫斯科能够束缚俄罗斯军队并破坏弗拉基米尔·普京政权的稳定。可惜的是， 叛乱是短暂的。最近几天，乌克兰军队在东部取得了小幅进展。但6月4日开始的反攻几乎没有迹象表明会很快突破俄罗斯的防线，这让一些西方官员感到紧张。

尽管如此，乌克兰还是从邻国的混乱中捞到了一些好处。其军队在东部城镇巴赫穆特取得了重大进展，普里戈任的部队经过近一年的战斗后于上个月才占领了该镇。乌克兰军队现在威胁要从北部和南部包围俄罗斯守军。乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基 (Volodymyr Zelensky) 在视察前线后于 6 月 26 日欢呼“快乐的一天”。 6 月 27 日，俄罗斯在晚餐时间对距离前线 30 公里的克拉马托尔斯克一家受欢迎的餐厅进行了导弹袭击。至少八人死亡，其中包括三名儿童。

对巴赫穆特的进攻的目的似乎不是进入这座城市，而是包围它。 “我们现在可以袭击城市中的任何地点和道路……我们正在努力切断他们的后勤，”在巴赫穆特北部作战的特种部队军官丹尼斯·雅罗斯拉夫西 (Denys Yaroslavksy) 说。军方发言人谢尔盖·切雷瓦蒂(Serhiy Cherevaty)证实，普里戈任叛变当天，多个旅已向巴赫穆特周围推进约2公里。

前线也转移到了其他地方。乌克兰占领顿涅茨克市西郊的领土尤为重要：军队进入了俄罗斯自 2015 年首次入侵乌克兰以来所控制的领土。再往西，在赫尔松地区，乌克兰军队在部分被毁的卡霍夫卡大坝线上方和下方建立了小型桥头堡。一些官员表示，乌克兰或许能够在未来几周内对迅速干涸的卡霍夫卡水库进行更大规模的穿越。

问题是俄罗斯的动荡是否会对战场产生更持久的影响。问题之一是瓦格纳集团的未来。 “他们与其他人的不同之处在于，他们只是冲锋陷阵，”巴赫穆特的一名士兵说。 “他们没有逃跑，因为如果他们撤退就会被枪杀。”这群人于五月下旬离开了这座城市，取而代之的是低素质的俄罗斯常客，但乌克兰希望他们能够返回。

一些武装分子确实已经返回乌克兰，普京表示他们将被吸收到俄罗斯军队中。其他人，包括参与叛乱的 2,500 至 5,000 名士兵，可能会在白俄罗斯加入普里戈任先生的行列。该国独裁者亚历山大·卢卡申科已提出使用一个废弃的军营，尽管乌克兰尚未看到任何证据表明其边境附近出现了设施。一名乌克兰政府高级官员警告说：“这些是可以用来执行牵制任务的专业部队。”一位军事情报人士表示，俄罗斯再次从北方入侵的可能性仍然很小。 “可能会有一场游戏让我们将部队转移到北方，”他建议道。 “但我们也玩游戏。”

第二个问题是对士气的影响。目前正在该市郊区作战的第 56 摩托化旅的一名发言人表示，自 6 月 23 日以来，她的同事们观察到俄罗斯同行的“混乱”程度达到了新的水平。他们的困惑是可以理解的。普里戈任现在坚称，他从来没有打算推翻普京。但在6月23日叛变前夕，他公开驳斥了有关乌克兰轰炸顿巴斯地区八年以及乌克兰和北约打算攻击俄罗斯的说法，从而公开驳斥普京的战争理由。他说，这场战争是为了俄罗斯“寡头精英”的利益而发动的。

在 6 月 24 日的愤怒言论中，普京本人不雅地将 1917 年进行了比较，这一年国内的革命导致了俄罗斯军队在法国的叛变。华威大学军事社会学家安东尼·金警告不要过度怂恿普里戈任先生的颠覆性信息的影响。他说，军队倾向于打仗有几个原因。政治原因只是其中之一。其他因素包括小部队内部的忠诚度，以及胁迫的影响——例如俄罗斯的“阻击分队”威胁要射杀撤退的士兵。金先生表示，他怀疑“政治恶作剧”是否会对战术层面的排和连产生很大影响。

叛乱引发的第三个问题对俄罗斯最高指挥部的影响可能更为严重。俄罗斯领导层内部的分歧和阴谋正变得越来越明显。 6月28日，《纽约时报》报道称，10月至1月俄罗斯驻乌克兰部队指挥官谢尔盖·苏罗维金将军事先了解叛乱事件。同一天，《华尔街日报》称，普里戈任打算在俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古和总参谋长瓦列里·格拉西莫夫将军访问乌克兰边境附近地区期间绑架他们。两份报告都援引了美国情报部门的说法。金表示：“指挥层的分裂可能会对竞选活动的团结产生长期影响。”

目前，乌克兰的进展速度比许多美国和欧洲官员所希望的要慢。英国陆军参谋长帕特里克·桑德斯将军爵士 (Sir Patrick Sanders) 6 月 26 日承认，“现在判断正在进行的反攻会取得多大成功还为时过早”，并补充道：“俄罗斯一直是一个东山再起的国家。”乌克兰尚未投入其大部分新的西方装备旅。但其最初对防御严密的俄罗斯阵地（包括雷场）的攻击暴露了其部队训练的有限性。据知情人士透露，他们造成了重大人员伤亡。

乌克兰指挥官希望保护其精疲力竭的部队；西方顾问反驳说，从长远来看，缺乏冲击和动力将导致更多人丧生。一名乌克兰军事情报消息人士抱怨说，考虑到现有的工具，该国正在尽可能快地采取行动。 “让我尽可能以外交的方式表达这一点，”他说。 “某些合作伙伴告诉我们继续前进并进行暴力战斗，但他们也花时间提供我们需要的硬件和武器。” ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 19:24:19 GMT /内容/m9jttfgjq99o9v5iceliio4vvfa3a6rh https://www.economist.com/europe/2023/06/28/can-ukraine-capitalise-on-chaos-in-Russia Sunday brunch is the new Friday night

加拿大的城市比美国的城市好吗？

EIU的宜居指数给出了答案

Covid -19改变了白领劳动力。封锁结束多年后，在家工作已成为标准。由此产生的对人们消磨时间的地点的影响已经引起了很多关注（在市中心的时间减少，在住宅区的时间增加）。但人们对这种转变如何改变人们的日程安排知之甚少。

理论上，远程办公应该让工作日变得更像周末。在家工作和周末都不需要通勤，在视频通话之间处理差事或聚会比逃离办公室更容易。然而信用卡数据显示，它产生了相反的效果：周末在面对面支出中所占的巨大份额进一步增长。

应我们的要求，全球最大的银行卡支付网络 Visa 分享了娱乐、食品和饮料、零售商品和交通支出的每小时数据，但不包括在线交易。这些数据涵盖了 2019 年 11 月和 2022 年 11 月六大洲的 22 个城市。他们跟踪了购买时间的变化，但没有跟踪总支出水平的变化。

在新冠疫情之前，刷卡的使用符合熟悉的模式。每天的支出激增两次，首先是午餐，然后是晚餐。周一至周六也缓慢上升，周五晚上达到顶峰。按GDP衡量 22 个城市，周五晚上 9 点至 10 点之间的支出占每周支出的 1.6%，是每小时平均支出 0.6% 的 2.7 倍。

到 2022 年，习惯发生了变化。工作日午餐依然强劲，但工作日下午 6 点至凌晨 12 点的支出比例下降了 2.7 个百分点。跌幅最大的是周四和周五晚上 9 点到 11 点之间，总共下跌了 0.7 个百分点。周末的支出份额相应上升，其中大部分增长是在白天。周六和周日的午餐增加了 1.2 个百分点。

有两个因素可能解释了这种转变。办公室人烟稀少，意味着下班后外出的人越来越少，许多餐馆、酒吧和俱乐部在封锁期间永久关门。如果远程办公人员在工作日需要使用笔记本电脑，而晚上可去的地方较少，那么周末就可以吸收他们的支出。

这两种趋势对于围绕疫情前生活方式建立的企业来说都是不利的。白天的平均交易量比夜间要少，从而减少了每个客户的收入，而容量限制限制了周末可以弥补工作日损失的收入。它们对于城市的社会结构来说也是一个坏兆头。许多地区受益于居民在离家较近的地方消费服务。但将晚间活动限制在周末会导致令人毛骨悚然的安静。 ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 19:08:37 GMT /内容/i3f73dm1r7i28pkm2ar2rpnbvmmskhbu https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/06/28/sunday-brunch-is-the-new-friday-night Can biology explain same-sex attraction?

同性吸引力存在于每个主要动物群体中，但是，像所有动物行为一样，它可能很复杂且难以研究。然而，潜在的生物机制对于了解人类健康、遗传学和进化非常有意义。研究人员知道不存在“同性恋基因”这样的东西。事实上，遗传学可以解释人们自我报告的同性行为中不到三分之一的变异。因此，非遗传因素发挥着巨大的作用。不过，科学家们对于这些因素到底是什么还没有达成一致。

《经济学人》的科学记者艾比·伯蒂克 (Abby Bertics) 参观了在库克姆举行的皇家学会关于同性吸引力的遗传学和进化的会议，会见了一些研究人员，他们对这些有趣的问题应用了科学严谨的态度。犹他大学心理学家丽莎·戴蒙德 (Lisa Diamond) 探索了一些与婴儿大脑发育相关的理论。普渡大学社会学家 Robbee Wedow 和赫尔辛基大学数据科学家 Andrea Ganna 解释了基因组研究如何将研究重点转向同性吸引力。此外，伦敦国王学院的心理学家卡齐·拉赫曼 (Qazi Rahman) 解释了为什么每个人都应该对同性吸引力的调查感兴趣。 《经济学人》科技编辑 Alok Jha 担任主持人。片长：46分钟

自 1991 年伊丽莎白·奥布埃扎 ( E LIZABETH Obueza) 的生活一直处于不稳定状态，当时她因担心生殖器被残割和作为一名政治活动家而受到迫害而逃离尼日利亚。她来到日本，日本是少数愿意向她发放短期旅游签证的国家之一。她的难民申请被拒绝，但通过重新申请，她设法留下来。由于没有工作许可，她只能靠发放食物为生。 2011年和2016年，当局突然将她抓捕并关押近两年，其中包括七个月的单独监禁。

奥布埃扎女士的困境太常见了。不到 1% 的申请人获得庇护——去年只有​​ 202 人，这个数字很惨，但仍然是迄今为止最高的。 （2021 年，德国接收了 39,000 名难民，是七国集团中最高的，其次是加拿大，接收了 34,000 名难民。）申请人的申请需要等待数年（平均四年，有时十年）才能接受审查，几乎没有什么权利，而且一直面临被拘留的风险。截至2021年底，有13,000名在日本的外国人正在申请难民身份。对他们来说，事情将会变得更加严峻。日本议会本月通过了一项修改法律的法案，以便可以将已经三次申请失败的寻求庇护者驱逐出境。

日本的老龄化社会越来越依赖外国人；过去十年中，移民工人的数量几乎增加了两倍，到 2022 年将达到 180 万。但政府仍然对难民采取强硬态度，认为有太多假难民滥用制度进入该国。事实上，人权律师指宿庄一表示，通过加大驱逐力度，日本政府正在为那些需要保护的人“按下处决按钮”。两年前，斯里兰卡妇女威什玛·桑达马利 (Wishma Sandamali) 在得不到医疗救治后在拘留期间死亡，该法案试图通过同一法案，但因公众强烈抗议而受阻。她是自 2007 年以来第 17 个在拘留期间死亡的人。（有些人正在绝食抗议。）

日本的难民政策似乎曾一度放松。俄罗斯入侵后，日本接收了2300多名乌克兰人。但与此同时，政府对联合国难民公约的解释更加严格，以排除那些逃离冲突的人。乌克兰人作为“准难民”或临时“撤离者”获得了一年的居民许可证。其他国家的人也没有受到类似的款待。居住在东京附近的库尔德男子尤塞尔·穆罕默德 (Yucel Mehmet) 很高兴乌克兰人受到欢迎，“但我忍不住希望他们只接受十名库尔德难民。”生活在日本的约 2000 名库尔德人中，只有一人获得了难民身份。

联合国敦促日本接纳更多难民。反对党议员石川大河表示，这个话题在日本从来都不是一个大问题，但该法案引发了“前所未有”的强烈反对。 6月8日，法案通过后，抗议者聚集在议会外，议员们在议会内发生扭打。活动人士希望在明年五月生效之前废除该法案。 “33 年来我一直在这里平静地生活，”奥布埃扎女士说。 “我恳求政府：给我们一个留下来的机会。” ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 17:58:35 GMT /内容/1hia788s3spqg1olrvf3o0932ig8fuov https://www.economist.com/asia/2023/06/28/japan-is-making-asylum-even-harder-for-refugees The working-from-home delusion fades

从 Zoom 到会议室的逐步反向迁移正在进行中。华尔街公司一直是最有力地召集员工到办公室的公司之一，但近几个月来，甚至许多科技巨头——苹果、谷歌、Meta 等——也要求员工每周至少三天到办公室。对于在家工作的信徒来说，这看起来像是企业脾气暴躁的报复。新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 大流行期间的大量研究不是表明远程工作往往比在办公室辛苦工作更有效率吗？

不幸的是，对于信徒来说，新的研究大多与此相反，表明办公室尽管存在种种缺陷，但仍然至关重要。一个很好的起点是一篇由当时哈佛大学博士生 Natalia Emanuel 和 Emma Harrington 于 2020 年发表的工作论文，该论文受到了广泛关注。他们发现，一家在线零售商的员工从办公室搬到家里后，每小时处理的电话数量增加了 8%。纽约联邦储备银行 5 月份发表的论文修订版则远没有引起人们的注意。效率的提升反而下降了 4%。

研究人员并没有犯错误。相反，他们收到了更精确的数据，包括详细的工作时间表。员工在远程办公时接听的电话不仅减少了，而且互动的质量也受到了影响。他们让客户等待更长时间。更多人也回了电话，表明存在尚未解决的问题。

这一修订是在其他得出类似结论的研究之后进行的。麻省理工学院的 David Atkin 和 Antoinette Schoar 以及加州大学洛杉矶分校的 Sumit Shinde 随机分配了印度的数据录入人员在家或在办公室工作。那些在家工作的人的工作效率比在办公室工作的同事低 18%。芝加哥大学的迈克尔·吉布斯 (Michael Gibbs) 以及埃塞克斯大学的弗里德里克·门格尔 (Friederike Mengel) 和克里斯托夫·西姆罗斯 (Christoph Siemroth) 发现，一家亚洲大型IT公司的远程员工的生产力与之前在办公室的表现相比，下降了 19% 。另一项研究表明，即使是国际象棋专业人士，在在线比赛中的表现也不如面对面的比赛好。还有人利用实验室实验表明视频会议会抑制创造性思维。

对于过去几年大部分时间都在餐桌上工作的人来说，这一发现的原因可能不会令他们感到惊讶。人们在家进行协作变得更加困难。美联储研究中的工作人员表示想念“可以向邻居寻求帮助”。其他研究人员查看了微软近 62,000 名员工的通信记录，发现公司内部的专业网络变得更加静态和孤立。电话会议是对现场会议的苍白模仿：例如，哈佛商学院的研究人员得出的结论是，许多公司在疫情期间推出的“虚拟饮水机”往往会占用拥挤的日程，但好处有限。用研究公司结构的经济学家罗纳德·科斯的术语来说，所有这些问题都意味着协调成本的增加，使集体企业变得更加笨拙。

随着人们习惯远程工作，远程工作的一些协调成本可能会下降。自 2020 年以来，许多人将熟练使用 Zoom、Webex、Teams 或 Slack。但随着时间的推移，另一个成本可能会上升：人力资本的不发达。在四月份发表的一项针对软件工程师的研究中，伊曼纽尔博士和哈林顿博士以及同样来自哈佛大学的阿曼达帕莱斯发现，在转向远程工作后，同事之间交换的反馈急剧下降。阿特金、肖尔和辛德博士记录了在家工作的人学习能力相对下降的情况。办公室里的人掌握技能的速度更快。

与上述观点相反，远程工作可以提高生产力的观点的起源可以追溯到大流行前近十年的一项实验，斯坦福大学的尼古拉斯·布鲁姆（Nicholas Bloom）等人在 2013 年报道了该实验。旅行社（现称为 Trip.com）在远程办公时的绩效提高了 13%，这一数字至今仍出现在媒体报道中。但有两个大问题经常被忽视：首先，超过三分之二的绩效改善来自于员工工作时间的延长，而不是效率的提高；其次，这家中国公司最终停止了远程工作，因为异地员工很难升职。 2022 年，布鲁姆博士再次访问 Trip.com，这次是为了调查混合工作试验的效果。这项实验的结果并不那么引人注目：尽管员工在办公室工作的时间更长，编写的代码也更多，但它对生产力的影响可以忽略不计。

幸福的代价

工作（和生活）不仅仅是生产力。也许远程工作的最大优点是它可以让员工更快乐。人们花在通勤上的时间减少了，从他们的角度来看，这可能会让人感觉生产力提高了，即使传统的措施无法检测到这一点。他们可以更轻松地适应学校接送和医生预约，更不用说偶尔睡个懒觉或上午慢跑了。一些任务——尤其是那些需要长时间集中注意力的任务——通常可以在家里比在开放式办公室中更顺利地完成。所有这些都解释了为什么这么多员工变得如此害羞办公室。

事实上，多项调查发现，员工愿意接受在家工作的减薪。反过来，以略低的工资让员工感到满意，对企业管理者来说可能是一笔划算的交易。对于许多人来说，未来的工作仍将是混合型的。尽管如此，每周的工作时间很可能会重新回到办公室，离开家——这并不是因为老板们都是受虐狂，对高峰时段的交通有怪癖，而是因为更好的生产力就在这个方向上。 ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 17:49:11 GMT /内容/n71bej4o0mid9rvpdte3q3qns9rum6su https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/28/the-working-from-home-delusion-fades Are Canadian cities better than America’s?

周日早午餐是新的周五晚上

封锁后，面对面消费已从工作日转移到周末

要阅读《经济学人》数据新闻的更多内容，请访问我们的图形详细信息页面。

联合国不向居住在美国或加拿大的工作人员发放艰苦工资。北美城市是世界上最适宜居住的城市之一——我们的姊妹公司经济学人智库 (EIU)及其宜居城市指数支持了这一观点，该指数可帮助雇主计算此类津贴。在这样一个有吸引力的地区，该工具还有另一个方便的用途：找出最好的与仅仅好的之间的区别。

EIU的全球指数对 173 个城市进行了五个类别的评判：稳定性、医疗保健、文化与环境、教育和基础设施。在北美（根据经济学人智库的方法，不包括墨西哥），所有 26 个城市的宜居性得分都至少为 80 分（满分 100 分）。塞班岛是个例外，它位于西太平洋的美国联邦北马里亚纳群岛。加拿大的城市一直表现出色，尤其是温哥华、卡尔加里和多伦多——在该地区排名前三，在世界排名前十。与此同时，在该指数 14 年的历史中，美国城市从未进入过全球前十名。火奴鲁鲁与蒙特利尔并列北美第四（世界第 25），是今年美国得分最高的城市。如何解释这种差距？

在这种情况下，尺寸很重要。加拿大城市受益于人口少：最大的是多伦多，人口略高于 280 万；温哥华大约有70万。同样，美国得分最高的城市——檀香山、亚特兰大（世界第 33 位）、匹兹堡（第 34 位）、西雅图（第 36 位）、华盛顿特区（第 38 位）和迈阿密（并列第 39 位）——都没有跻身美国十大城市之列。按人口。檀香山和匹兹堡各只有约 30 万人口。 （肯塔基州列克星敦——得分最低的北美城市——规模相当，但教育得分相对较低。）纽约是美国最大的城市，拥有 850 万人口，在与繁荣大都市相关的设施方面得分很高：基础设施良好、充满活力文化和强大的教育体系。但人口越多，风险就越大：其稳定性得分是北美最低的（与莫斯科惊人地持平）。

稳定类别考虑了犯罪率以及恐怖主义、内乱和军事冲突的威胁。大流行期间，美国各地的犯罪率激增。在纽约，枪击事件已大幅下降，但袭击和汽车盗窃等重罪仍然居高不下。 2022 年，随着破坏性的反疫苗抗议活动席卷全国，占领城市并封锁主要街道，加拿大的稳定性得分出现了波动。但这些已经结束了，与美国相比，犯罪率和恐怖主义威胁要低得多。

最后，加拿大城市擅长提供高质量的公共医疗保健。他们的南部邻国确实看到了该类别的改善，与一年前相比，其改善足以推高该地区的整体指数得分。 EIU 将其归因于 covid-19 病例的减少以及与大流行相关的医疗保健系统压力的减轻。尽管如此，美国的关键健康指标——例如预期寿命和孕产妇死亡率——仍比加拿大差得多。

当然，宜居性对于每个城市居民来说意味着不同的东西。纽约的狂热喧嚣、檀香山的新月形海滩、蒙特利尔的鹅卵石街道——这些都能整齐地映射到索引上吗？也许不是。但就一座城市的可衡量品质而言，看看美国在哪些方面可以赶上是很有用的。 ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 17:03:28 GMT /内容/s9j1n8418jnpru55q95onsv714q580o7 https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/06/28/are-canadian-cities-better-than-americas Why Britain must end its use of short prison sentences

英格兰和威尔士关押了很多人——比任何欧盟国家都多。因为监禁可以让那些对公众构成危险的人远离街头，所以它很受欢迎。但对犯罪的惩罚力度越来越大，加上未能提供足够的牢房和警卫，意味着监狱变得拥挤和暴力。因此，尽管政府表示改造是监狱的主要目标之一，但他们往往无法改造罪犯。

监狱改革是一项吃力不讨好的工作。被视为对罪犯软弱并不能赢得选票。然而政府可以采取一个简单的步骤来改善监狱。每年大约有 60% 的任期持续时间从几周到 12 个月不等。这些短句收效甚微，但研究和常识表明它们会造成严重伤害。是时候进行一些新的思考了。

一年以下的刑期主要针对非暴力、程度较低、惯犯、生活困难的人。他们中的大多数人都有吸毒、酗酒或心理健康问题——有时他们三者兼而有之。他们中的许多人无法读书或保住工作。短暂的监狱生活让他们的生活变得更加混乱。

它们也使监狱更难管理。新入狱的短期囚犯是内部走私毒品的主要渠道。混乱的短期服刑者可能会让那些因更严重的犯罪而服刑较长时间的人感到不安。大量短期囚犯造成的流失也是监狱工作人员流动率高的一个原因（见英国部分）。

限制短刑的论点对于女性来说尤其引人注目，因为她们中的大多数都犯有轻罪。他们只占被监禁者的一小部分，但他们的监禁时间可能会造成极大的破坏。妇女往往承担着抚养孩子的主要责任。当母亲进入家中时，她们的孩子通常也被迫搬家，有时进入寄养家庭或国家机构。 That may be one reason why the children of imprisoned mothers are more likely to end up in the criminal-justice system themselves.

The government could vastly reduce the use of short sentences by passing legislation that sets a higher bar for imprisonment. The new approach would create a sentencing threshold. For example, shoplifting, the crime that most commonly now lands people in prison for short spells, could be prevented from carrying a custodial sentence. (This would work better than introducing a presumption against short sentences, which might result in some people being put away for longer.)

To make that happen, the alternatives to prison need to work better, too. Sentences that require work in the community already result in lower reoffending rates than short prison terms. But they could be better designed. For example, people often fail to complete the required hours of service. These need to be enforced. For that, the dysfunctional probation service, which is supposed to oversee community sentences, needs to be restored to health. Magistrates, who preside over the lower courts, could do with better training in the merits of keeping minor offenders in the community. They sometimes resort to jail because they have seen that community sentences fail badly. They do not grasp how prison fails even worse.

Most important is to mandate treatment for offenders with drug, alcohol or mental-health problems. And that is true not just for light sentences. Many long-term prisoners also need medical help. Punishment remains a crucial part of sentencing. Yet for many of those inside it is pointless, even cruel, if it does not also tackle the causes of their offending. ■

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 16:41:53 GMT /content/95hm8usavht4ml31ul121cpr3pb8bvb9 https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/06/28/why-britain-must-end-its-use-of-short-prison-sentences Narendra Modi’s ultimate test—educating 265m pupils

C LOSING THE factory in the north-Indian state of Uttar Pradesh was not a decision he took lightly, says the boss of a manufacturer based in Mumbai, India's business capital. Yet the local workforce's lack of skills and discipline meant it made sense to produce in the south and west. “We offer training at all our production sites, but bringing people to the required level simply wasn't worth our time.”

The tale illustrates one of India's biggest problems. Its education system is failing it. At some 1.4bn, it has more people than China, and its economy is growing fast. It needs to make hundreds of millions of its young people employable, particularly in the poorer, more populous northern states. Otherwise it could waste much of its growth potential and court instability as undereducated, underemployed youngsters lose hope.

Graduates of its leading universities are high-flyers at the world's best firms. But many of the 265m pupils enrolled in its schools will leave them barely able to read or do basic maths. aser, an annual survey of children in rural India (three-quarters of the total), found that in 2022 just a quarter in Year 5 (when they are ten) could do basic division and a mere 43% managed to read a Year 2-level text. Of those in Year 8, when compulsory education ends, barely 45% could do basic division and less than 70% could read a Year 2-level text.

Even more alarming is the lack of progress. Though school infrastructure and enrolment have improved in recent years, with more children attending schools that have toilets, running water and sometimes even computers, learning has not kept pace. By 2022, maths skills had barely budged in a decade; reading skills had declined, partly owing to learning lost during the covid-19 pandemic. These numbers hide regional variations; learning levels tend to be higher in richer southern states and lower in the poorer north.

One reason is a long-standing focus on elite education inherited from British rulers, keen to train administrators to run the empire. Post-independence governments relied on a small, brainy elite to build the new nation. “It's a sorting mechanism, a system for the first two rows of the class,” says Yamini Aiyar, who heads the Centre for Policy Research ( CPR ) in Delhi.

The system's narrow emphasis on finishing a rigid syllabus assumes skills few children have when they start school—and never get a chance to acquire. It does little for the vast majority of pupils at non-elite government or low-cost private schools. Yet they are the ones India's economy needs to broaden from its focus on services and increase its heft in manufacturing, which it hopes will account for 25% of GDP in 2025, up from 17%. Even a factory job requires skills many school leavers lack.

Some signs of change can be seen. On a recent afternoon in Bajraha village in Bodhgaya in the east-Indian state of Bihar, a dozen children in their early teens sat in a circle in the village hall as Bajanti Kumar, a local volunteer, drew letters on a blackboard. In their summer holiday the children were learning how to read a simple story and do basic maths, things they had not learnt in four years at school. The programme, organised by Pratham, an Indian nGO , along with the state government, aims to stop them and some 1.5m other children across Bihar falling further behind in the new academic year. Similar efforts are afoot in Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh, reaching some 3.3m children.

Such catch-up activities are welcome, but cannot fix the system's many problems. Attendance by children remains poor, with the national average at around 70% and closer to 50% in states like Bihar. Teachers in government schools are well-paid, but penalised little if children fail to learn anything. Data published in 2017 showed that a quarter of spot-checks found teachers absent from schools.

Fixing those problems requires complex cultural change, says Ms Aiyar of cpr . One state-level government that has done more than most is in Delhi, India's capital, under the Aam Aadmi Party ( AAP ). Starting in 2015, it massively boosted spending on education. The aim was to improve infrastructure and the quality and accountability of teachers and administrators in its secondary schools through a combination of curriculum reform, training and community involvement. The approach worked: for the past eight years, formerly grotty government schools in the city have done far better than private ones.

Modified ambitions

Narendra Modi's government has been less decisive. When he took office in 2014, he promised that national spending on education would rise to 6% of gdp, close to what is spent in Brazil (6%) or South Africa (6.6%). Yet on its own figures it has never cleared the 3% mark, though the World Bank, source of the figures for the other countries, puts it at 4.5%. His government has also made alarming moves to “rationalise” textbooks, stripping them of references to undesirable subjects, from India's Muslim heritage to the theory of evolution.

Yet it has begun to overhaul the education system. A national policy, published in 2020, wants every year-3 pupil to achieve basic reading and maths skills by 2027, a welcome if wildly ambitious target. As in Delhi, teachers are being urged to forsake rigid adherence to the curriculum for teaching at their pupils' actual level. More emphasis is put on pre-primary education, one of the most cost-effective ways to improve learning. The policy also provides for improved teacher-training, reduced non-teaching responsibilities and performance-based rewards.

Such efforts are better than simply spending more, says Karthik Muralidharan, an economist at the University of California, San Diego. Cheap interventions such as learning camps can help a lot.“ He adds that “volunteers can be very effective as supplemental instructors”, as they are local and so “more connected to the pupils”. Deepak Kumar, a 24-year-old university graduate who runs a summer catch-up camp from his family home in Bihar's Gaya district, plans to support his pupils for the next year as he swats for government exams; no child has ever missed a class of his.

The covid-19 pandemic, when schools remained closed for the best part of two years, highlighted the importance of parental involvement in education, says Rukmini Banerji, who heads Pratham. Nearly a third of children now receive extra private tuition, up from a quarter five years ago. Policymakers want to deploy parental interest more systematically, setting up school-preparedness camps for mothers of children starting school and keeping them engaged through simple technology tested during the pandemic, such as videos, audio stories or texts with suggestions for activities. At one camp The Economist visited in Pune, Maharashtra's second city, mothers were full of praise for the approach. “I always struggled to understand what my children were doing at school. Now I feel like I have a bigger stake in it,” says Sushma Deshmukh, the mother of a ten-year-old.

Yet technology is not the magic fix for government failure that many in India's burgeoning ed-tech sector once imagined: Byju's, an education startup from Bangalore which as late as April said it offered online classes to as many as 150m students, was this week scrambling to reassure investors after it lost three board members and its auditor.

Working out which reforms ultimately make the biggest difference will take years. Most important, says Mr Muralidharan, the government has to stay on the case. “They need to put in place independent mechanisms to measure what works, accept the results, and adjust policy accordingly.” Given the government's aversion to data that contradict claims about its success, that may be too much to hope for. ■

T uberculosis (TB), which kills one person every 20 seconds, is a forgotten pandemic. About a quarter of the world's population has been infected with the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis . Most will never know, as they are asymptomatic. But these latent infections go on to sicken about one person in ten. And even though TB is treatable, around 1.6m people each year, mostly in poor countries, nonetheless die from it.

A 100-year-old vaccine, the BCG , has helped, but it is only partially effective. On June 28th two of the world's wealthiest charities, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and Wellcome, said they would fund a late-stage trial of a new TB vaccine known as M 72. That will cost $550m, of which the Gates Foundation will contribute $400m, making it the charity's biggest ever investment in a single product.

M 72 is a “sub-unit” vaccine. Rather than a dead or weakened form of the bacterium itself, it contains two proteins found on the bug's surface. GSK , a big pharmaceutical firm, acquired it from Corixa, an American company, in 2005. Early trials, the results of which were published in 2019, concluded that it was about 50% effective in preventing TB in the lungs of those with a latent infection—a group in which no other vaccine has worked. But gsk decided developing the vaccine further would not be commercially viable.

That is where the charities come in. The Foundation will not only pay for most of the bigger trial that is required before the vaccine can be approved by regulators, it will also sort out the logistics. It has identified a dozen sites in Africa and Asia where rates of latent tb infection are unusually high, between 40% and 60%. Testing here will allow scientists to see more quickly whether the vaccine prevents the emergence of active TB . But the trials will still take four to six years, says Trevor Mundel, president of global health at the Foundation. That is one reason for the high cost; others include the number of participants required—around 26,000—and the cost of setting up laboratories.

If the new jab really is 50% effective, it could save 8.5m lives, and prevent 76m cases of TB , over the next 25 years. It could also avert 42m courses of antibiotic treatment, which might slow the rate at which TB is evolving resistance to such drugs.

Academic and charitable support for vaccines is not new. But such organisations can only do so much. The vaccine will ultimately need a commercial partner to put it through regulatory assessments and organise sales and distribution. Pharmaceutical firms also conduct post-marketing surveillance, which helps regulators spot side-effects that might have gone unseen during the trials themselves. Despite their financial firepower, “there is no way Wellcome and the Gates Foundation can…become a vaccine company,” says Mr Mundel. Other vaccines, such as one for Lassa fever being developed by the non-profit group IAVI , remain in commercial limbo for such reasons.

Wellcome and the Foundation hope to secure a commercial partner for their jab within 12 months. Indian vaccine-makers, which are more used to investing in developing medicines for low and middle-income countries, seem interested. An earlier GSK vaccine for malaria was licensed to Bharat Biotech, an Indian firm, in 2021. As for all the new trial sites built for testing M 72, Mr Mundel is hoping the investment may also be of use to others wanting to test future vaccines. BioNTech, a German firm, is developing an m RNA vaccine to target TB , for example. With a growing pipeline of drugs and vaccines for TB , optimism over better treatments is growing—even if getting them to market needs a helping hand from charities. ■

G etting into Jinjiang Ode is a little difficult. The luxurious property development in central Chengdu will not allow potential buyers through its four-metre-high palatial gates without an appointment. Even finding out about the project in the south-western metropolis, home to 16m people, is tricky. The firm behind it is so confident of demand that it does not deign to advertise the flats—a confidence which is not unjustified. Chengdu has a distinct, laid-back atmosphere epitomised by its public tea gardens, in which patrons spend hours sipping hot beverages and having their ears cleaned. The leisurely pace of life and tongue-numbing local cuisine appeal to younger Chinese people, who have come in droves in recent years, says Zhang Xiaojun, a sales agent at the development. Many of them buy homes.

As a prolonged downturn in China's property market takes hold, Chengdu seems to be an outlier. By several metrics, including house prices and sales of new homes, it is faring better than almost anywhere in the country. At a national level, the central government's response to the deepening property crisis, including an interest-rate cut announced on June 13th, has underwhelmed. China's benchmark stock index has fallen by 8% since its peak this year in early May, when the country still appeared to be rocketing towards a full post-covid recovery . Now investors fear more developers will start to fall short of cash, defaulting on dollar debts in the process. Experts are asking how much local measures can pump up growth. Chengdu is a good place to search for answers.

There is a faint air of unreality about the local market. New home sales between April and June were 30% higher than in the same period in 2019, the last year before the covid-19 pandemic struck, notes Larry Hu of Macquarie, an investment bank. In contrast, across China's 30 largest cities, sales have fallen by 25%. Meanwhile, in May home prices in Chengdu rose by 8% compared with the previous year, the most of any large city. It has notched month-on-month rises for 17 straight months. Many Chinese cities are working through vast inventories of flats that have been built but not sold: it will take the southern city of Zhuhai more than 12 years to sell homes that have been completed or are still under construction if sales stay at the current pace. Chengdu will sell such flats in just over three years.

What explains the success? Since 2016 officials in every Chinese city have been able to devise their own measures for cooling or heating local property markets. Most of the rules employed are restrictions on who can buy a flat, how many they may purchase and the size of the downpayment required. In most large cities, only people with local hukou , or residence permits, are allowed to buy homes. In Chengdu, high-level purchase controls remain in place. But officials have sought to attract families as a way of expanding the city and increasing demand for homes. Residents with two or more children are, for instance, allowed to buy additional homes, and local hukou- holders may buy up to three. Even those without a hukou may buy two. Since the start of the year, elderly parents who move to Chengdu to join their adult children may also purchase a flat.

Other cities have experimented with similar policies, but enjoyed much less success. Shenzhen, the technology hub across the border from Hong Kong, has relaxed some of its restrictions. Yet property prices are still down 1.8% year-on-year. One explanation for this is sweeping layoffs in the city's tech sector. Another is that Chengdu's policies are more effective because they are paired with reforms to attract educated workers, which have helped boost growth. Since 2017 local authorities have handed out housing subsidies and cash rewards to talented people who move to the city in order to work in its rapidly growing industrial base, points out Sandra Chow of CreditSights, a research firm.

Chengdu's officials also did a better job of tackling the crisis of confidence that spread across the country last year. As developers went bust, many failed to finish flats. Thousands of homebuyers responded by halting mortgage payments. Many more delayed buying new homes. Officials in Chengdu went to great lengths to ensure homes were handed over, funnelling cash to developers, says Ms Chow. Even defaulting developers managed to complete homes. About 40% more apartment space was finished in the first two months of 2023 compared with the same period the year before. This probably encouraged wavering buyers to take the plunge. Other regions may have wanted to follow suit, but lacked the cash. Sichuan, where Chengdu sits, notched up the strongest growth in municipal land sales of any province in the first half of 2022, which will have freed up funds to keep builders at work.

Chengdu benefited from some other factors that will be difficult, if not impossible, to replicate elsewhere, and perhaps even in the city itself. Its population rose by more than 7m from 2011 to 2021, making it one of the fastest-growing urban areas anywhere in the world. These inflows have been the biggest driver for housing demand, says Yan Yuejin of E-House China, a research firm. But urban migration has since slowed. There are simply not enough people in China for another population boom. Chengdu's location in the south-west also meant it did not see rapid rises in prices in past housing booms. Moreover, its growing manufacturing industry continued to lift incomes. As Louise Loo of Oxford Economics, another research firm, notes, it is thus one of just a few second-tier cities that have not seen rapid price increases relative to local incomes.

A few levers remain for Chengdu's officials should things start to look peaky. They have yet to drastically ease restrictions, allowing many more people to buy homes. Market-watchers are waiting for such a development, says Guo Jie of the Local Association of Real Estate Enterprises, an industry group, for it would indicate that steam is running out and that even the best-prepared cities are being swept into the crisis. Policymakers elsewhere in the country will be watching closely, too. ■
